content:
The blacksmith's 
 dilema 
 
 Ugandan folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time in a mountainous 
 African vilage there lived a famous 
 blacksmith. 
 
 The vilagers caled him Ratshipi - the 
 man of iron and stel. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ratshipi was known by everyone in the
 
 vilage. 
 They went to his shop every morning to
 watch him work. 
 
 He semed to be able to make anything
 with his iron and stel. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Kgosi Mogale, the vilage chief, heard 
 
 about Ratshipi’s work. 
 He sent his servants to bring Ratshipi to 
 the palace. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ratshipi was hapy to hear that Kgosi
 
 Mogale wanted to se him. 
 “I wil be very hapy to work for the
 chief,” he said. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Ratshipi went to the palace. 
 
 “Ratshipi, I have heard about your god 
 work,” said Kgosi Mogale. 
 “I want you to do a very special task.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “With your iron and stel, I want you to
 build a man who can walk, cry real tears
 
 and bled real human blod.” 
 “Imposible!” thought Ratshipi. But no
 one could say no to the king in this
 
 vilage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ratshipi could not slep that night. 
 
 How was he going to do this imposible 
 task? 
 He was very scared and very woried. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly Ratshipi remembered a wise
 
 old man Rapule. Perhaps he could help.
 
 But where was Rapule? He had 
 
 disapeared from the vilage. People said
 that it was because he had displeased
 
 the chief. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next morning Ratshipi did not go to 
 his shop. 
 
 He went up the mountains to think. 
 
 While walking there, he saw an old man 
 
 siting under a tre. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was old Rapule! 
 
 “I am so pleased to se you,” said 
 Ratshipi. 
 “I have a big problem.” 
 
 He told Old Rapule the whole story. 
 Old Rapule thought carefuly, and then he 
 
 said… 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Tel the chief that you wil ned a
 thousand buckets ful of tears and a
 thousand African pots ful of hair. With
 
 the water, you wil make blod. With the
 hair, you wil make a fire to strengthen
 the stel man.” 
 
 “Thank you, thank you!” Ratshipi said,
 runing back to the palace. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ratshipi said, “Kgosi Mogale, to do what 
 
 you ask, I wil ned two things. A 
 thousand buckets ful of tears; and a 
 thousand African pots filed with hair 
 
 from the heads of the vilagers.” 
 Kgosi Mogale agred. He asked his 
 
 headmen to tel the vilagers. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Cries were heard from every corner of
 
 the vilage. Young and old people cried
 day and night to fil a thousand buckets
 with tears. 
 
 Every vilager’s head was shaved of and
 thrown into the pots. 
 
 
 But the tears and hair of al the vilagers
 were not enough to fil the buckets and
 
 pots. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Eventualy Kgosi Mogale gave up and 
 
 caled Ratshipi back to the palace. 
 “Ratshipi, you are a wise man, the wisest 
 in the vilage,” said Kgosi Mogale. “Wil 
 
 you do me the honour of being my chief 
 headman?” 
 
 Ratshipi smiled. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Only if you let old Rapule come back to
 the vilage,” he replied. 
 
 
 So Ratshipi became chief headman.
 And he and old Rapule were the advisors
 
 of Kgosi Mogale.
